parts:
Give a critical analysis of the following podcaset transcript

---

Introduction

Mike Green: Welcome to the Asia Chessboard, the podcast that examines geopolitical dynamics in Asia and takes an inside look at the making of grand strategy. I’m Mike Green of the United States Studies Centre in Sydney and the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Welcome back to the Asia Chessboard. I’m joined by Ja Ian Chong, an associate professor of political science at the National University of Singapore, a rising and influential IR scholar about the region, a student of Tom Christensen, and introduced to me by my friend Ford Hart, who has decamped to Singapore—one of the State Department’s great China watchers over the years. Ian, great to have you on the show.

Ja Ian Chong: Thanks for having me on.

Early Interests and Path into International Relations

Mike Green: We always start by asking how you got into this. Obviously, you’re in Singapore, you’re in Asia. All Singaporeans are taught about geopolitics in school—not detailed IR, of course, but a sense of Singapore’s unique position. What got you into the international relations field and off to Princeton for a doctoral degree?

Ja Ian Chong: I’d always been interested in politics, even as a kid, and for some serendipitous reason, I found international politics—especially security—fascinating. That’s something I figured I would do. It’s quite funny because I’ve actually known of you and we’ve probably met several times a long time ago. I went to Georgetown as an undergraduate and was in DC for a while after that. I worked at CSIS under the International Security Program—this would be the early 2000s—so I’m sure our paths must have crossed. It was interesting because at that point I was figuring out whether I would do more of a policy route or academia. My time at CSIS was very exciting and very fun, but it also taught me that, perhaps for my own constitution, I’m more suited to taking a step back, looking at conceptual dynamics, rather than doing day-to-day policy.

Mike Green: So you were there in the heyday of security studies. That would have been Kurt Campbell, Michèle Flournoy, Derek Mitchell.

Ja Ian Chong: That’s right. I worked for them.

Mike Green: Big strategic thinkers. And then that launched you to Princeton. Your work is interesting and multi-dimensional, but one thing you do—which is very much a Tom Christensen thing and something I enjoy—is hybrid history and political science. You did a piece that caught my attention about World War I—1914—what the lessons are and aren’t for geopolitics in Asia. Let’s start with the big question: how worried are you about the prospects for war? How confident are you about stability when you look at the conditions before World War I?

World War I Lessons and the Risk of Crisis in Asia

Ja Ian Chong: That piece—which I did with my good friend and colleague Todd Hall—looked at dynamics unfolding in Asia about ten years ago and what was going on in Europe around the centenary of the First World War. Looking at what’s going on now, I don’t think actors in Asia actively want a conflict. But we’re tying ourselves up in knots in terms of various interests. Our ability to signal is getting muddied by all kinds of issues entering the information stream. My concern is we could stumble into some sort of crisis that escalates out of control. It doesn’t matter whether that’s the Yellow Sea/West Sea, the East China Sea, Taiwan, or the South China Sea. In some ways they become one theater, because if you think about escalation not just in intensity but geographic scope, it’s difficult for the region to escape escalation once it starts. I would prefer more active thinking about conflict prevention. We didn’t see enough of it when Todd and I wrote the article, and I still don’t think we see enough today.

Mike Green: Odd Arne Westad gave a great presentation at Aspen, drawing parallels—history rhymes, it doesn’t repeat—between Asia today and Europe before 1914, and China with Germany. One I’ve long found dangerous is how much the German staff—the Schlieffen Plan—let military planning dominate grand strategy. The plan to defeat France by invading Belgium made military sense, but it was terrible grand strategy because it brought in Britain, and with Britain you got a million Indian troops, the ANZAC Corps, the Canadian Corps, and eventually over four million Americans. To me that’s an eerie precedent for what China seems to be doing. The military dimension makes sense as a military plan to complicate and push back allied responses, but it’s creating bandwagoning against China. What’s your assessment of China’s grand strategy? Is it self-defeating or quite successful? Does it evoke those World War I worries?

China’s Strategy, Nationalism, and Escalation Risks

Ja Ian Chong: It certainly does. There’s not just the dominance of highly securitized thinking; the PRC today isn’t just doing military activity. They’re happy to do a lot of gray-zone and hybrid things that can be quite escalatory. If the point is to quickly seize and control areas, like the Schlieffen Plan, I see the logic. But that sort of thinking doesn’t account for other variables—bandwagoning effects, knock-on effects for other interested actors. Look outside East Asia: Europeans were far less focused on Asia a decade ago. With supply chain issues, PRC efforts to support Russia in Ukraine, and then robust—sometimes risky—Chinese gray-zone and military activity, Europeans got a lot more interested in Asia. We’re seeing some of that interest grow—maybe at a slower pace than 1914—but certainly the PRC’s ability to control escalation is risky. I’ll add another concern: the strong nationalism the current PRC leadership is cultivating. That was another aspect of World War I. Everybody was very confident in their militaries and national capabilities. Pride swelled and created overconfidence. We may be seeing that today. Ultimately some leader makes a call; if they judge wrongly, that can be the trigger.

World War II Echoes: Ideology and Economic Decoupling

Mike Green: Some historians think applying historical precedent is bad practice, but why study history if not to draw lessons? It’s à la carte, not a set menu. The other precedent that jumps out is World War II, particularly the Pacific War: economic decoupling with the Great Depression and Smoot-Hawley, and an ideological battle. World War I wasn’t ultimately an existential ideological contest. The war in Asia was a battle between a Japanese vision—anti-Western Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere, anti-colonialism—versus the West. Now our Chinese friends emphasize “Asia for Asians” versus the West. It’s almost like the worst precedents from World War I mixed with the worst from just before World War II. The ideational East versus West, and economic decoupling—does that make this more dangerous than before World War I?

Ja Ian Chong: The economic decoupling and the deep suspicion—partly ideological—also mean mechanisms that could roll back or slow down crises are a lot weaker today. That’s a big concern. On the rhetoric—yes, the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere—a lot of rhetoric out of Beijing today, and if you overlay that sphere with the nine-dash line and the First Island Chain, it’s not completely the same, but there’s a big area of overlap. On the PRC side, there’s a worry about encirclement, suppression, containment—a concern they could be cut off. That sounds very much like Japan in the 1930s. The response is strikingly similar in ways I find scary: break out by controlling access a lot more and denying access to rivals. Couple that with greater confidence and delegating action to military or paramilitary forces. That’s maybe a bit different from the first or second world wars, but it could trigger snowball effects that would be really hard to roll back.

Singapore’s Strategic Dilemma and ASEAN’s Limits

Mike Green: From Singapore’s perspective, to manage security and prosperity you need more, not less, economic interdependence—sorry, the trend is the other way. You need pragmatism over ideology—sorry, not happening; it’s increasingly ideological. You need decisions driven by economic growth, not autarky or war planning—sorry, not happening in China, and increasingly the U.S. and even allies emphasize economic security, accepting relative gains over absolute gains for secure supply chains and to avoid coercion. All the trend lines are bad for Singapore’s basic view of survival. The government’s clearly unhappy. Do you sense ferment in Singapore about changing strategic assumptions—how Singapore or ASEAN have agency? Publicly there’s pining for the old liberal order. Singaporeans are pragmatic. What are you hearing among scholars and government about agency—positioning Singapore when the world’s not listening to Lee Kuan Yew or Goh Chok Tong or Lee Hsien Loong? Is there ferment about new strategic agency?

Ja Ian Chong: My sense—and you’ve probably heard this at Aspen and elsewhere—is many in the Singapore establishment and foreign policy circles realize some things need to change. What that strategy is or ought to be is not entirely apparent to me. There are aspects: emphasis on needing more and better partners, deepening engagement with India and the European Union, also Australia, Korea, Japan. There’s the idea that if we work on these things, we can bring more actors into East Asia with a stake in stability, and maybe that could work. It’s a modification of what we had previously. But if we’re heading in a very different trajectory—and there’s a good argument we are—it’s not clear what the next step is for Singapore. Singapore enjoyed a privileged and fortuitous period for a long time. For all the rivalry between the U.S. and the PRC, there was a belief in Washington and Beijing that cooperation had to win out. That is going away, if it hasn’t already. For countries like Singapore, “not choosing sides” was possible when, if you didn’t work with one major actor, they didn’t punish you for it; if you worked with the rival on areas in your interest, you wouldn’t get punished. These days we’re seeing Singapore getting hit with some of the tariffs. We just had the cyberattack allegedly from the PRC. Trying to get a break from both sides is becoming increasingly difficult. So what do you do? There’s some feeling around, but the big vision isn’t quite there yet. There continues to be a lot of reference to Lee Kuan Yew, which I’m skeptical about because he lived in a very different environment. His playbook tells us what would work in that Cold War context. What it tells us about today is less clear. He was in a period of more economic liberalization and globalization. We’re moving in the opposite direction. Some of those basic operating assumptions don’t hold the same way. If Singapore is serious about institutions, talks more about principles and agency—which officials do—then there has to be thinking about the international system and institutions. Are there things we want to salvage and save? If so, who do we work with to get those outcomes? Are there things on which we need to take more initiative? Are there areas where we need to push for reform? ASEAN is due for reform. It performed quite well; it did many useful things for Southeast Asia in calming things down. But it’s designed to slow tensions and make everything calmer. By virtue of slowing things down effectively, it is very inert in its ability to take initiative. So when you have a crisis, ASEAN gets stuck.

Rethinking ASEAN: From “Cow” to “Tractor”

Mike Green: Bilahhari Kausikan’s line—don’t expect ASEAN to be a thoroughbred; it’s a cow, it can do what a cow does, but not a horse.

Ja Ian Chong: Yes, Bilahhari Kausikan said ASEAN’s a cow, not a horse; you can’t expect it to do what a horse does. I get where he’s coming from. Many older establishment people around ASEAN make that claim—don’t fix what’s not broken. But I would argue maybe we don’t need a cow these days; maybe we might not even need a horse. Maybe we need a tractor. It’s about fitting capabilities to the situation we face. ASEAN might be a great cow, but if we don’t need a cow today—or need less of a cow—and we need other things, then that debate is moot.

Mike Green: What does that ASEAN that’s not a cow or a horse, but more of a tractor—with more horsepower—look like? Sometimes younger, forward-thinking scholars and officials in Indonesia or Singapore or Thailand talk about a coalition of the willing within ASEAN, a smaller grouping—Singapore and Indonesia at the core—that can move without being paralyzed by consensus or held back by countries closer to China’s orbit. What does that tractor ASEAN look like to you?

Ja Ian Chong: A couple of things. Conceptually, ASEAN needs to recognize there are coordination and collective action problems it has to solve, and be serious about them. You need to set up processes. When you have a Myanmar crisis like we did, you don’t just put together an envoy, cobble together a Five-Point Consensus, and then leave where you go from there unclear. You need more planning and better coordination. I understand reform is difficult—touching the Charter or basic treaties is hard—but within the existing context there’s low-hanging fruit. For instance, with the Secretariat: you don’t have to give it more authority—which many capitals are wary of—but you could give it more capability to do what it’s already empowered to do better. Increase its budget, increase the size of the bureaucracy that helps address some of the overhead costs of putting together the thousands of ASEAN meetings, and harmonize issues on the table, so things aren’t so ad hoc. That’s straightforward and possible. It requires resources, attention, and political will, but that’s a first step. We’re not seeing that right now.

Minilateralism, Multipolarity, and the Costs of Agency

Mike Green: What about leveraging multipolarity within Asia—like the U.S., Japan, Australia, and India have with the Quad; Australia and Japan deepening their bilateral defense relationships; the “Squad” with the Philippines? What about more active Singaporean participation in these minilaterals? Beijing calls them “small NATOs” and doesn’t like them. Singapore is active with the U.S.—the Strategic Framework Agreement, Talisman Sabre exercises. But what about a more deliberate harnessing of multipolarity to deepen defense, economic security, and diplomatic cooperation with key powers that are not ASEAN and not broad multilaterals? It seems to me Singapore could be doing more.

Ja Ian Chong: Multilateral and minilateral approaches are something Singapore can explore more. But engaging in them is not cost-free or risk-free. As you mentioned, the PRC sees some of these as mini-NATOs, adding to claims of encirclement, suppression, and containment. If Singapore is interested in keeping aspects of the rules-based order—openness and stability—then it needs to figure out how to invest in these and the costs it’s willing to pay. There will be pressure from Beijing on some issues; there could be pressure from Washington as well. You have to take that in stride and understand your appetite. The issue is that Singapore, like many Southeast Asian states, has been in a very comfortable situation for a long time, with a willingness to delegate—if you’re being polite; free-ride, if less polite—on the efforts of other actors. If you have problems in Southeast Asia, let the Americans and Chinese talk it out. If you have issues in Northeast Asia, the Northeast Asians will take care of it. Singapore is a little more forward-leaning than some neighbors, but it can certainly do more if it really wants stability. All the multilateralism and minilateralism is positive for Singapore. A multipolar world would be more challenging, because multipolar systems often involve regional leaders—regional hegemons—who decide to carve out areas for themselves. Singapore and Southeast Asia have been successful because we can connect different actors together—be a conduit for trade, investment, innovation. Being locked into spheres of influence would cut against Singapore and Southeast Asia’s strengths.

Leadership, Ideas, and Singapore’s Institutional Culture

Mike Green: One of Singapore’s assets is intellectual—embodied in Lee Kuan Yew, and in the excellence of the bureaucracy and universities. George Shultz told me he got interested in Asia at Princeton, wrote about the Pacific before Pearl Harbor, and then Nixon sent him to meet Lee Kuan Yew. Decades later, Lee Kuan Yew would come see President George W. Bush and give strategic advice—on Taiwan, China, Japan. Singapore, frankly, has lost that. The newer generation doesn’t have that gravitas. It wasn’t just Lee’s world experience; it was the grand strategy of Singapore. Singapore’s own national power depends on getting this back on track—figuring out these questions—because otherwise the impression in Washington or Tokyo will be that Singapore wants to go back to the old days, and we can’t. If any country can do it, it’s Singapore, but my sense is it’s not there yet. Is that fair?

Ja Ian Chong: I think that’s fair. I’d be a little more pessimistic. Lee Kuan Yew was a one-off. People talk about him as exceptional. If that’s the case, exceptions are one-offs; they’re not the rule. What he could do is probably not available to current leadership. We have to recognize that and not keep going back to the Lee Kuan Yew playbook. You can’t replicate it. More broadly, one thing I’ve observed—you might have too—is that Singapore’s system doesn’t provide the same space for people who are willing to come up with bold ideas and put their foot forward as much anymore. You mentioned Bilahhari Kausikan, Tommy Koh, Chan Heng Chee, and—whether you agree with him or not—Kishore Mahbubani. These folks are at least in their 70s if not 80s. Who is the next generation?

Mike Green: All very smart, sometimes controversial people, and all had the protection of Lee Kuan Yew. Chan Heng Chee—a good friend of mine, long-serving ambassador to the U.S.—was a critic of Lee Kuan Yew, so he brought her in and made her ambassador. If someone was a true big thinker, not just a thorn in his side, he’d promote them. The system is different now, isn’t it?

Ja Ian Chong: Right. You can’t think of a next generation of people. In some ways Singapore is a victim of its own success. In Lee’s period, the system was not as institutionalized. As someone who likes institutions, it’s odd to say, but because it wasn’t, it had space for ideational entrepreneurs—people to come up with new ideas and try them. If you could win over Lee—and it wasn’t just Lee; people like S. Rajaratnam, Goh Keng Swee, Hon Sui Sen, Toh Chin Chye were important—if you could win over these people, you’d get a shot. As we’ve become more professionalized, bureaucratized, and institutionalized, you’ve got to follow the rules and tracks. That means people with new and different ideas could find it more difficult to showcase what they have. Over time, people get frustrated and figure: why am I busting my head trying to get an idea across when, because of my rank or seniority, it doesn’t get heard? I might as well make money in the private sector.

Mike Green: Henry Kissinger’s book “Leadership” profiles Lee Kuan Yew and others. One takeaway is leadership is becoming bureaucratized and institutionalized. Leaders like Lee or Margaret Thatcher endured great hardship and trauma—the Japanese conquest of Singapore, being kicked out of Malaysia—huge traumas that forged toughness and wisdom. This is not just Singapore’s problem. Across the Indo-Pacific, you have strong leaders—Modi, Xi Jinping, I suppose Trump—but not wise leaders. In many countries—Japan, Korea, Australia—you have leaders who are not bold. Institutions, the burdens of older economies, frustrated publics—there’s a macro problem. It’s a lot like 1895–1914: Bismarck was gone; even the British—Edward Grey—blew it before World War I. The statesmen who built the Concert of Europe left, and you had more bureaucratized people. Leadership is probably another worrying parallel.

Ja Ian Chong: Leadership is important. Perhaps what friends outside Singapore and many Singaporeans don’t appreciate enough is that Lee, for all his larger-than-life persona, was in his early cabinets first among equals. He had a team around him—Goh Keng Swee, S. Rajaratnam, Hon Sui Sen, Toh Chin Chye—people willing and able to stand up to Lee. That helped them get better at policy. Lee was the outward-facing person, but they had big fights about where to go. The fact they had these fights and could respect each other helped course-correct. In Singapore’s system today, the PAP leadership claims this still exists, but it’s less obvious that there are real efforts to come at problems from different angles and figure out what’s best. That fit for Singapore is a bit lost.

Tariffs, Unpredictability, and Business Models

Mike Green: It would also apply to Zhongnanhai with Xi Jinping, and the White House with Donald Trump—leaders not surrounding themselves with people who feel free to challenge them. It’s no secret the Singaporean system is profoundly unhappy with Donald Trump’s foreign policy, especially his economic policy. Just before we talked, the U.S. and Japan reached an agreement on tariffs. It seems these “deals” are starting to happen. The new world looks like 15% tariffs. That’s not good for growth in my view, but it’s possible we’ve reached an equilibrium—less drama and unpredictability that hinder investment, defense cooperation, and diplomacy. We don’t know what this agreement with Japan means, but I’m a little less pessimistic we may reach a new equilibrium—not ideal, with higher tariffs, but more stable. What’s your take on the Trump approach to the region, Southeast Asia, the role of tariffs, and how it’s viewed?

Ja Ian Chong: The unpredictability the Trump administration brought makes Southeast Asian governments and businesspeople uneasy. That includes many Singaporean leaders, hence the criticisms and complaints. But it’s the world we have, and we have to deal with it. It also means we have to rethink some of our business models. Previously, a lot of discussion was about removing trade and investment barriers, including tariff and non-tariff barriers. That’s not happening now. A lot of the system also worked on looking at the U.S. as a final market. Tariffs complicate things beyond bilateral issues. Take Singapore: it receives a lot of capital—its largest investor in FDI terms is the U.S., also the EU and Japan; they’re much bigger than China, and also various tax havens. What happens to that money when it comes to Singapore? Some of it produces services and goods we then sell to the region for them to produce and then sell to the U.S. market. Or Singapore exports that capital—we’re a big capital exporter to Vietnam, the PRC, Thailand, Indonesia—where our firms set up subsidiaries and factories to produce. Tariffs break that circulation. If Singapore firms invest in, say, Indonesia, and Indonesia faces—what is it—19% under the deal, it’s more difficult to sell into the U.S. That means lower demand, and our prosperity is likely lower. We have to deal with those knock-on effects. The fact that the Trump administration tends to change its mind even after making deals also makes people uneasy, especially because business and policy need longer-term plans. It’s difficult to do that when you fear there could be a change within weeks or months.

Mike Green: If you have to pick your poison, you’ll take 15% tariffs and stability over 15% tariffs and unpredictability—with the possibility of new tariffs and an inability to plan. Stability and predictability are not adjectives that usually go with President Trump, but he likes to win and doesn’t like to lose. I have no doubt people like the Treasury Secretary, Scott Besson, are telling him growth depends on more predictability than we’re giving right now. We’ll see. It’s crucial to Singapore.

Taiwan: Stability, Democracy, and Regional Stakes

Mike Green: Quick last question—or second to last—about Taiwan. You’ve done a fair amount of work on Taiwan. Being a Tom Christensen student, I’d expect no less. Singapore has a unique relationship with Taiwan, including military dimensions, and has stood up to Chinese pressure. What’s your take on the Taiwan situation, how Singapore’s thinking about it, and the impact for Southeast Asia? A lot of people worry that the chance of war—Chinese use of force or coercion—is going up. What’s your take?

Ja Ian Chong: For Singapore, the overriding concern is a stable region, and Taiwan sits astride Northeast and Southeast Asia. If Singapore wants to do business with Northeast Asia, the area around Taiwan has to be stable. That’s the primary concern. But with increased PRC pressure on Taiwan, that lends itself to instability, unpredictability, and escalation. Singapore and other Southeast and Northeast Asian states need to emphasize that any resolution has to be handled without coercion, without the use of force. Many governments, including Singapore, are wary of punishment from China, so they’ll say this—but up to a point. I don’t think the message is getting through enough. That applies to the South China Sea and East China Sea as well. On the historical relationship between Singapore and Taiwan, I think one area not fully understood about Taiwan is: this is not the KMT’s authoritarian, martial-law-era Taiwan anymore. They are a democracy, and what their people believe and think is good for them matters a lot more now, and that has to factor into any consideration. Unless you’re going to accept PRC rolling over Taiwan—which would get resistance, whether or not it’s effective—it would be highly disruptive. The point is to avoid that. Some of the lag in thinking comes from an assumed familiarity with Taiwan from past interaction—party ties between the KMT and the PAP. They had more interactions before; there’s less familiarity with the DPP. The bureaucracy may be different, but at least on the party side that’s true. This is born out of a close but fairly quiet relationship. Taiwan is Singapore’s fifth-largest trading partner and a large investor. That continues. On what you were referring to earlier: the longstanding unilateral training we have in Taiwan—our armed forces essentially rent land from Taiwan to train. There are specific reasons. If you think about where the Imperial Japanese military trained before invading Malaya, it was southern Taiwan. So there are similarities in geography that are useful. Some of the training has been scaled back as places in Australia have become available. It’s not a secret, but it’s not widely publicized, that the ROC military had a big role in helping Singapore set up our armed forces—especially the air force and the navy. Some early senior leadership in the air force and navy were ethnic Chinese from Southeast Asia who had served their careers in the ROC navy or air force, and then were brought over to set up our air force and navy in Singapore.

Theater-Wide Coercion and Regional Responses

Mike Green: The ties that Singapore, Japan, and others have to Taiwan are deep and interesting. But the general debate about Taiwan in governments in the region—outside Japan—is a bit outdated and doesn’t fully take into account a democratic Taiwan. It’s convenient to assume Taiwan is not democratizing, or to see democratization as a problem because it brings out voices that upset China. Other than Japan—and I suppose the U.S., although there are problems—a lot of governments haven’t adjusted to the new reality and what’s at stake. People also haven’t adjusted to the new Chinese leadership. For a long time, leaders in China were willing to live with—unhappy, but willing to live with—a certain space for Taiwan. That’s decreasingly the case with the current PRC leadership. If you look at the Anti-Secession Law and explanations, anything short of Taiwan accepting PRC control can be couched by Beijing as destabilizing and provocative. Many regional governments are not willing to challenge that view that Beijing is pushing the envelope much more than before. The other thing governments need to wake up to: the PLA’s campaign plan for coercing Taiwan is not a cross-Strait campaign; it’s a theater-wide campaign. You can see rehearsals in the PLA Navy surface action group that circumnavigated Japan, actions in the Yellow Sea west of Korea, the South China Sea, and between Guam and Japan. These maneuvers are portrayed in national presses as bilateral problems, but they’re not. It’s a pattern and part of a broader Chinese strategy. Militaries and intelligence services know that. It gets back to the strategic wisdom of the Schlieffen Plan versus grand strategy—the folly of aligning all your adversaries. We’ll see if it does, but conditions are ripe for governments—if we can sort out tariffs and so on—to work in concert.

Ja Ian Chong: The issue for a lot of Southeast Asian governments—including my own in Singapore—is that there is understanding of the situation you’ve described, but also a belief that the Americans will take care of it, the Japanese will take care of it, together with the Australians. We just have to lean back, not get our hands dirty, and see how we can profit. This fairly opportunistic and passive approach is exactly what could get us into trouble if we want to avoid World War I or World War II scenarios. If governments were more active in saying, “We’re not going to accept the use of force. You have your differences; resolve them in other ways,” there could be a much stronger voice. But there’s a lot of unwillingness. Look at UNCLOS and the arbitral tribunal ruling with the Philippines—that’s international law. Singapore and others say international law is important, UNCLOS is important, but they’ve largely backed away from talking about these things because they’re afraid of PRC punishment. If this is something you believe in and think is important, you have to put your money where your mouth is.

Gray-Zone Pressure and Societal Resilience

Ja Ian Chong: I’d add one more element about the theater: the gray-zone stuff, which I find very concerning. The PRC is engaging, in the pre-crisis or pre-conflict phase, in a lot of information operations, cyber activities, and influence operations in Southeast Asia, which is highly pluralistic, playing on cleavages. I can understand from Chinese interests why you’d do it, but it could really rip at the fabric of these societies, including in Singapore—playing different actors, playing on the ethnic card. That could be very dangerous and is underappreciated. Security services are aware of it, but at the political level there’s concern that if you go hard on this, it could really upset Beijing—so let’s not do that.

Mike Green: Fragmenting societies and weakening national resolve is the whole point. We’ll see if governments wake up to that beyond just the security services and police.

Closing

Mike Green: We could keep going for hours—great, wide-ranging discussion. We did leadership, history, IR theory, Singaporean bureaucratic politics. Many thanks, Ian—Ja Ian Chong, associate professor of political science at the National University of Singapore. We’ll look for your next great work and have you on again.

Ja Ian Chong: Thank you so much.

Mike Green: For more on strategy and the Asia Program’s work, visit the CSIS website at csis.org and click on the Asia Program page. And for more on the United States Studies Centre in Sydney, please visit ussc.edu.au.

This podcast episode offers a wide-ranging and unusually candid assessment of strategic risks in Asia, using historical analogies (World War I, World War II, interwar Japan) to illuminate current Chinese behaviour, regional fragility, and Singapore’s policy dilemmas. Below is a critical analysis organised by major thematic areas.

---

## 1. Use of Historical Precedent

Both Mike Green and Ja Ian Chong lean heavily on the World War I and II analogies. The Schlieffen Plan parallel is well chosen in highlighting the danger of military operational logic crowding out grand strategy. The point that pre-1914 leaders underestimated escalation dynamics—and that East Asia’s maritime flashpoints could merge into a single theatre—is analytically strong.

However, the conversation risks over-reliance on historical rhyming. The risk is that the analogy can shape threat perception more than ground reality warrants, potentially reinforcing a self-fulfilling prophecy of confrontation.

Chong’s warning about PRC influence operations exploiting ethnic and political cleavages in Southeast Asia is one of the most under-acknowledged but urgent themes.
